item.title: Live Updates: Israeli Strikes Rock Lebanon as Iran’s Leader Issues Warning
item.description: It was not clear if the attack had killed its target, the presumed successor to Hezbollah’s slain leader. In Iran, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei threatened further attacks on Israel. At the White House, President Biden suggested Israel should consider alternatives to striking Iranian oil facilities.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Why Us?’: A Tide of Grief in Lebanon
item.description: Mourners reeled over lost loved ones after an Israeli strike on an apartment building killed at least 45 people.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Mom, I Want to Live’: A Young Girl Battles War and Cancer
item.description: Sonya Liakh was diagnosed with eye cancer at age 2. After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupted her treatment, her family faced a desperate struggle.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario
item.media:description: Sonya Liakh was 2 years old when she was diagnosed with a rare form of eye cancer.

item.title: The U.K. Has a More Working-Class Cabinet. It’s Still Seen as Out of Touch.
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s top team contains more lawmakers from poor backgrounds, and fewer from elite schools, than any in recent memory. Voters haven’t noticed.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner, right, and other British cabinet members at the Labour Party’s annual conference last month. She was raised in public housing and left school at 16.

item.title: After Successes, Israel’s Military Is in a ‘Long Game’ With No Clear Outcome
item.description: A year after perhaps the worst military and intelligence debacle in the country’s history, its armed forces have regained the momentum. Some ask: to what end?
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles at a staging area near the border with Lebanon on Sunday.

item.title: Gang Attack in Haiti Leaves 70 People Dead
item.description: The assault took place in a key agricultural region, which has seen a surge in gang violence.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The attack happened in the Artibonite department, where criminals have increasingly invaded farmland and set up roadblocks on the highway to kidnap drivers.

item.title: E.U. Court Says Some Rules for Soccer’s Transfer Market Are Illegal
item.description: A decision could force soccer’s governing body to rewrite the regulations that govern the sport’s multibillion-dollar transfer market.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Lassana Diarra, right, went to court after being fined millions of dollars for walking away from his contract and trying to join a new club.

item.title: Bosnia Balkans flooding rains
item.description: A severe overnight rainstorm in the Balkans left several towns and villages flooded. Record summer temperatures had caused a drought that hampered the absorption of floodwaters.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Flooding on Friday after heavy rains in a village near the Bosnian town of Fojnica, about 30 miles west of Sarajevo.

item.title: Gender Identity Changes Must Be Recognized Across E.U. Borders, Court Rules
item.description: A man who changed his name and gender identity in Britain successfully challenged to have them legally recognized by Romania. “I’m representing everyone who is affected.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Pride Parade in Berlin in 2023. Rights campaigners say a court ruling may give transgender people more freedoms throughout the European Union.

item.title: Israeli Planes Bomb Bunker Near Beirut, Targeting Hezbollah’s Presumed Next Leader
item.description: The airstrikes were aimed at a meeting of senior Hezbollah leaders in an underground bunker early Friday, and targeted a cousin of Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman, Liam Stack, Lauren Leatherby and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath in Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday after an overnight explosion.

item.title: After Iran’s Missile Attack, Israel May Be Ready to Risk All-Out War
item.description: Israel seems ready to respond in a much more forceful and public way with Iran after Tehran launched its second massive missile attack on Israel this year, analysts and officials say.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Eric Schmitt and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building in Hod Hasharon, Israel, that was destroyed during Iran’s missile attack on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel’s Strikes in Beirut Brings the Once-Bustling Suburbs to a Standstill
item.description: Airstrikes targeting members of Hezbollah have brought the Dahiya neighborhoods south of Beirut to a standstill, its residents fleeing and businesses shuttering.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed street in Dahiya, the predominantly Shiite southern suburbs of Beirut, after a barrage of Israeli airstrikes, on Wednesday.

item.title: Amid Sanctions, Russian Oil Tankers Are Flying New Flags
item.description: A shadowy network of ships has registered in Gabon, highlighting how Vladimir V. Putin is building an economy beyond the reach of Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Jacob Judah
item.media:description: Dozens of tankers have registered in Gabon over the past year, records show, making that country’s ship registry one of the fastest-growing in the world.

item.title: Putin Tries to Recruit More Soldiers, Encourage Bigger Families
item.description: President Vladimir Putin is throwing ever more resources at two interlocked priorities: recruiting more soldiers and encouraging bigger families.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A military recruiting poster in Kursk, Russia, in August. President Vladimir V. Putin has ordered the ranks of Russia’s army to increase by 180,000 service members to 1.5 million.

item.title: A Pentagon Debate: Are U.S. Deployments Containing the Fighting, or Inflaming It?
item.description: Military officials discuss whether sending more force to the Middle East is helping to prevent a much wider war, or emboldening Israel.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: K.C. Alfred/The San Diego Union-Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln and its strike group of destroyers and fighter squadrons has been monitoring Iran from the Gulf of Oman since August.

item.title: Iran’s Foreign Minister Conveys Support for Joint Cease-Fire in Lebanon and Gaza
item.description: Iran’s top diplomat appeared eager to convey Iran’s readiness to support a joint cease-fire in Lebanon and in Gaza — even as Iran’s supreme leader at home expressed readiness to fight Israel.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Russia and Syria Silent on Reported Strike Near Russian Base in Syria
item.description: A weapons facility near a Russian air base in a coastal Syrian city was destroyed on Thursday, according to a monitoring group.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson, Anton Troianovski, Aric Toler and Oleg Matsnev

item.title: Hamas Leader Is Holding Out for a Bigger War, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Yahya Sinwar is increasingly fatalistic, has blocked a cease-fire deal and, so far, been frustrated that Hezbollah and Iran have not come to his aid, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, in Gaza in April 2023. The group has shown no desire at all to engage in talks in recent weeks, U.S. officials say.

item.title: What Game Theory Tells Us About the Threat of an Israel-Iran War
item.description: Each side must predict how the other will react to avoid mutual destruction.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction is seen in a Dahiya neighborhood south of Beirut after a week of deadly Israeli airstrikes.

item.title: Here Are the Hezbollah Leaders Israel Has Targeted
item.description: Israeli strikes have aimed to kill the leaders of the Lebanese militia, most recently Hashem Safieddine. It was not immediately clear whether he had been killed in an overnight strike near Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Lauren Leatherby

item.title: Champions League’s New Format Creates a New Reality
item.description: This year more than ever is showing that the competition means different things to different clubs. And that’s a good thing.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Tiago Santos and Lille may already have their biggest win of the season.

item.title: Ayatollah Khamenei Praises Oct. 7 Attacks and Warns Israel in Rare Sermon
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who led Friday prayers for the first time in years, called for pan-Muslim unity against Israel and the United States at a memorial service for Hassan Nasrallah.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of supporters gathered to hear Iran’s supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, lead Friday prayers in Tehran.

item.title: Israel Expands Evacuation Warnings in Southern Lebanon After Renewed Strikes
item.description: Israeli soldiers were also waging a ground invasion in southern Lebanon targeting what military officials said were Hezbollah sites in the rugged border area.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over the Dahiya area south of Beirut, in Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: What to Know About the 2024 Nobel Prizes
item.description: The annual prizes will be announced beginning Monday.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Replicas the Nobel Peace Prize medal on display at The Norwegian Nobel Institute in Oslo.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Targets Hezbollah’s Remaining Leaders
item.description: Plus, a billion-dollar plan to protect trees.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Beirut’s southern suburbs.

item.title: A Rest, a Reset and a Thanks for the Banter
item.description: After more than 350 editions, we are putting this newsletter on pause, with the editor who opened the Australia bureau departing and his successor set to arrive.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damien Cave at the Sydney office of The New York Times in October 2017.

item.title: Yazidi Woman Taken Captive by ISIS Has Been Rescued in Gaza, Israel Says
item.description: She was returned to her family in Iraq after a complex operation involving the United States, Jordan and others, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video posted on Thursday on the X account of an Israeli diplomat, showing Fawzia Amin Sido, 21, reuniting with her family in Iraq.

item.title: Who Is Hashem Safieddine, a Possible Nasrallah Successor Targeted by Israel?
item.description: A cousin and possible successor to Hassan Nasrallah, the Hezbollah leader assassinated by Israel, Safieddine joined the group soon after it was formed and rose quickly up its ranks.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Hashem Safieddine, the head of Hezbollah’s Executive Council, attending a ceremony in Beirut’s southern suburbs earlier this year.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Kills at Least 18 People in the West Bank
item.description: The high toll and Israel’s use of a warplane were unusual for the Israeli military’s operations in the West Bank, which have escalated during the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: The bodies of the Palestinians who died in an Israeli strike in the West Bank city of Tulkarm on Thursday were taken to the Sabit State Hospital morgue.

item.title: How 2 Offhand Remarks by Biden Caused Waves in the Markets and the Middle East
item.description: The president’s casual disclosures underscored the power of his words — and how quickly they travel.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden responded to reporters’ questions at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Expands Evacuation Orders in Lebanon
item.description: Plus, paying countries to protect trees.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: An Israeli airstrike on the town of Khiam, Lebanon, yesterday.

item.title: What to Know About the Marburg Virus Disease Outbreak
item.description: In Rwanda, 11 deaths have been reported from this rare but deadly disease. Two people tested negative in Germany this week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and April Rubin
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Image Point FR/National Institutes of Health/National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases/BSIP/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
item.media:description: A colorized scanning of an electron micrograph shows Marburg virus particles (in blue), both budding and attached to the surface of infected cells (in yellow).

item.title: The S.S. United States May Soon Find New Life on the Florida Seafloor
item.description: The S.S. United States, one of the fastest ships to ever cross the Atlantic Ocean, may be sunk off the coast and turned into a habitat to marine life as the world’s largest artificial reef.
item.dc:creator: Kate Christobek
item.media:description: The S.S. United States, once a luxury vessel in trans-Atlantic waters, may soon end up on the sea floor off the coast of Florida as a home for marine life.

item.title: Oil Prices Jump After Biden Says ‘Discussing’ Potential Israeli Strike on Iranian Facilities
item.description: The president was asked about a potential strike on the oil infrastructure of Iran, which accounts for about 2 percent of the world’s supply.
item.dc:creator: Jason Karaian and Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden spoke to the news media as he prepared to board Marine One from the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Unable to Penetrate Systems, Hackers Spread Lies About Vulnerabilities
item.description: When France fended off cyberattacks during the Olympics, hackers circulated false claims about their attacks, a tactic the United States could face during the election.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Rory Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: American officials warn that while election systems may be secure, hacker groups may try to spread disinformation to disrupt next month’s election.

item.title: A NOAA Climate Agency in Asheville Was Knocked Out by Helene
item.description: The National Centers for Environmental Information in Asheville, N.C., sweep together data from around the world to help track Earth’s warming.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: The Veach-Baley Federal Complex in Asheville, N.C., which houses the National Centers for Environmental Information, in May 2021.

item.title: Masamitsu Yoshioka, Last Pearl Harbor Bombardier, Dies at 106
item.description: He was 23 years old when he took part in the attack that triggered America’s declaration of war against Japan. He rarely spoke publicly about it.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Europe Expected to Approve Higher Tariffs on Electric Cars From China
item.description: The European Union is expected to support wielding tariffs on electric vehicles made in China, seeking to prevent unfair competition.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: European countries are set on Friday to approve additional tariffs of up to 45 percent on Chinese-made electric cars, aiming to protect European automakers from an influx of cheaper, state-subsidized vehicles.

item.title: Russia, U.S. and Other Countries Are Evacuating Their Citizens from Lebanon
item.description: Several countries have chartered flights, while others issued warnings and offered assistance.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Arriving in Bulgaria onboard a government plane from Beirut on Monday.

item.title: U.K. to Hand Over Chagos Islands to Mauritius, Ending Colonial-Era Dispute
item.description: After years of legal wrangling and negotiations, Britain said it would surrender sovereignty of the archipelago in the Indian Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Diego Garcia, the largest island in the Chagos Archipelago, is the site of a major military base used by Britain and the United States.

item.title: Abuse Claims Add to Telegram C.E.O. Pavel Durov’s Legal Troubles
item.description: The mother of three children with Pavel Durov has poked holes in the Russian tech titan’s carefully managed image through a criminal complaint and her account of their opulent lifestyle.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Clara Watt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irina Bolgar said she had a romantic relationship with the Telegram founder Pavel Durov for about a decade.

item.title: The Whiskey Industry Is Bracing for a Trade War if Trump Wins. It’s Not Alone.
item.description: Business owners and foreign governments are preparing for high tariffs and trade disruptions, depending on the outcome of the election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sonat Birnecker Hart, owner of the Koval Distillery in Chicago. The prospect of renewed trade wars make it hard for businesses like hers to plan for the future.

item.title: A Climate Fund Could Pay Billions to Protect Trees in Amazon and Beyond
item.description: Brazil is proposing a fund that would pay countries to protect tropical forests that are crucial to curbing climate change. It would generate returns, too.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Garo Batmanian, the director of the Brazilian Forest Service and one of the architects of the Tropical Forests Forever Facility, in the forest bureau in Brasilia.

item.title: S. Iswaran, Ex-Singapore Minister, Sentenced to 1 Year in Prison
item.description: The sentence for S. Iswaran, a former transportation minister who pleaded guilty last week, was longer than what prosecutors had sought.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: S. Iswaran, the former transportation minister of Singapore, had pleaded guilty to charges of accepting gifts that included tickets to the play “Hamilton.”

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Strikes Leave 6 Dead in Beirut
item.description: Plus, new evidence in the Trump election case.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Dahiya, a densely populated area south of Beirut.

item.title: Krathon Storm Brings Flooding and Landslides to Taiwan
item.description: Two people have been killed and more than 10,000 evacuated, the authorities said. The drenching rain brought damage and widespread power outages from the storm, downgraded to a depression.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and John Liu

item.title: Mexican Military Fatally Shoots Six Migrants
item.description: The country’s defense ministry said the military officers who opened fire might have mistaken the migrants for cartel members.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and James Wagner
item.media:description: Members of the police and Mexican Army patrolling in the Tila community in Chiapas, Mexico, in June.

item.title: ‘There’s No Safety’: Decision to Leave Ends in Tragedy for Lebanese Family
item.description: Zahraa Badreddine fled Nabatieh in southern Lebanon as Israeli airstrikes intensified, hoping to find safety in a predominantly Christian area closer to the coast. But last Sunday, an airstrike near Sidon killed her two children.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel, Meg Felling and Arijeta Lajka
item.media:credit: Matthew Cassel for The New York Times

item.title: Gilead Agrees to Allow Generic Version of Groundbreaking H.I.V. Shot in Poor Countries
item.description: Many middle-income countries are left out of the deal, widening a gulf in access to critical medicines.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A vial of lenacapavir, an injectable H.I.V. prevention drug. A generic version will be sold in 120 countries, but a few large countries, which together account for 20 percent of new infections, will not have access to a low-cost version.

item.title: Israeli Strikes on Gaza Schools and an Orphanage Kill Scores of Palestinians
item.description: The Palestinian Authority’s official news agency said the Israeli military operation had included an incursion by ground troops and airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Rescuers from Palestinian Civil Defense extracting a body from a collapsed building in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Says at Least 8 Soldiers Are Killed in Clashes With Hezbollah in Lebanon
item.description: The cross-border fighting appeared to be the first direct ground confrontation between the two sides since Israel invaded Lebanon this week.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank in a staging area near the Israeli-Lebanon border on Tuesday.

item.title: In Israel, Rosh Hashana Is More Bitter Than Sweet
item.description: On Rosh Hashana, many Israelis longed for a return to normalcy after a year of escalating wars for the country.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Family and friends of an Israeli soldier who was killed in Lebanon, at his funeral on Wednesday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: White South African Farmer Accused of Feeding 2 Slain Black Women to Pigs
item.description: The grisly allegations have set off debate over some of the country’s most explosive issues, including race, gender-based violence and farm ownership.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: People outside court in Polokwane, South Africa, on Tuesday, where three men have been accused of killing two women who went to a farm looking for food.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Israeli Troops Clashed with Hezbollah
item.description: Plus, what we learned from fashion month.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Maroun El Ras in southern Lebanon yesterday.

item.title: Israel-Hezbollah War: What to Know
item.description: An Israeli ground operation targeting Hezbollah forces in Lebanon recalls previous wars and raises fears of worse to come.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles in a staging area near the border with Lebanon on Tuesday.

item.title: A Survivor of Clerical Sex Abuse Tells His Story at the Vatican
item.description: As a child, Laurence Gien was abused by a priest in South Africa. Decades later, he became the first survivor to recount his pain at the Basilica in front of Pope Francis and dozens of cardinals and bishops.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Laurence Gien on Tuesday at St. Peter’s Basilica, where he recounted having been abused as a child by a priest in South Africa. He told his story with Pope Francis in attendance.

item.title: Biden Says He Won’t Support an Israeli Strike on Iran’s Nuclear Sites
item.description: His comments reflected a renewed effort by his administration to seek restraint from Israel to try to avoid a growing war in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Wednesday
